Dear Mr. Alward,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me.
In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177 Resident Restraint
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was restrained. Youth has fractured wrist. It is unknown if
the fracture was a result of the restraint.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via
telephone on 1/17/23 as well as face to face on-site at the
facility in conjunction with the MDHHS on 1/19/23. During the
interview on 1/19/23, Assistant Superintendent was also
present. Within days prior to Youth A arriving at the facility, he
was in a car accident, but the facility was not made aware of the
accident when he was admitted. Due to lack of notification, they
followed normal protocol of the nurse assessing him within 7 days
of admission. Assistant Superintendent reported she spoke with
Youth A the morning of 1/11/23 and he stated his wrist felt
different and asked to see the nurse. During the conversation,
Youth A never alleged his wrist injury or wrist hurting was a result
of the restraint from 1/10/23. The nurse was supposed to see
Youth A on 1/9/23 or 1/10/23, prior to the restraint, however Youth
A was yelling in his room, so the nurse saw him on 1/11/23. CA
reported if staff cannot comply with CPI restraint methods, the
expectation is to be reasonable in efforts to protect staff and
youth, which includes holding onto a youth until help arrives.
Youth A was interviewed via video conference on 1/17/23.
Youth A reported he did not know how his wrist got injured and it
never hurt prior to arriving at the facility. He stated he was
admitted to the facility on 12/29/22 and it started hurting about 2
weeks after he got to the facility. Youth A reported he put in a
request to see the nurse when he saw a cyst returned. He showed
there was a cyst on his left wrist (very top of wrist/bottom of his
hand) and reported cysts have been an ongoing issue for him in
that spot. He reported he had the first cyst about 2 years ago,
went to Urgent Care and it went away after the doctor gave him a
wrist brace. He reported he had an X-Ray completed last week,
which showed he had a wrist fracture. The doctor did not share a
2

timeframe for when the fracture occurred. Youth A denied any
other events, fights or impacts to his wrist that could result in a
fracture. He reported during the restraint on 1/11/23, Supervisor
grabbed Youth A around his waist and pulled him to the ground
because Youth A was trying to fight with Youth B. Youth A
reported he had his eyes closed and does not know who else
restrained him. Youth A stated he was laying with his stomach
towards the ground. Youth A reported Supervisor’s forearm was
on the back of his neck, he stated he couldn’t breathe, and
Supervisor moved his arm to Youth A’s head instead. Youth A
stated his left arm was not grabbed during the restraint, but it was
positioned under Supervisor’s body and/or leg during the restraint.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with the MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Youth B stated Youth A became escalated during a
Group Assistance Meeting and attempted to start a physical
altercation with him. Youth B reported Youth A shoved Staff 5 into
a door, she fell to the ground, and other staff responded quickly.
Youth B stated Supervisor was the first person in the room and
grabbed Youth A from behind to stop him from attacking anyone.
He reported he did not see anything else because he went to his
room when the other staff came in.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 1 reported she was the last staff member to
enter the pod. When she entered, Youth A was laying with his
back on the floor and Supervisor was holding him down by his
chest area. She stated she could not tell which part of
Supervisor’s body was on Youth A’s chest, but no part of
Supervisor’s body was on Youth A’s wrist. She stated she helped
secure the room, and when she was done, Staff 2 and Staff 3
were helping Youth A to his feet as he had calmed down.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 2 reported Youth A was laying with his back
on the floor and Supervisor was holding Youth A down by his
chest area. Staff 2 noted specifically Supervisor’s forearms were
on Youth A’s chest. Staff 2 stated while Supervisor was holding
Youth A down, Youth A was kicking, yelling, and screaming and
Supervisor was attempting to verbally de-escalate Youth A and
was asking Youth A to stop. Youth A threatened to bite
Supervisor. At one point, Youth A stated he could not breathe
twice, and Staff 2 stated Supervisor adjusted his position
3

immediately. Staff 2 reported Youth A’s hands were wrapped
around Supervisor’s thigh, so Staff 2 loosened Youth A’s grip and
secured Youth A’s right arm while Staff 3 secured Youth A’s left
arm. Staff 4 and Staff 5 secured each of Youth A’s legs.
Supervisor was then able to get up and step away. Staff 2
reported Staff 3 lightly patted Youth A’s chest and repeatedly
instructed Youth A to breathe to help Youth A calm down. After
Youth A was calm, Staff 2 and Staff 3 helped Youth A to his feet,
each held one of his hands and guided him into his room. Staff 2
stated Youth A did not verbally disclose or physically demonstrate
any type of pain associated with his wrist during or directly after
the restraint. Staff 2 reported he did not see anything Supervisor
did that could have caused injury to Youth A’s wrist because
Youth A’s arms were wrapped around Supervisor’s leg. Staff 2
stated Youth A never complained about any pain or medical
issues during any of his conversations with Youth A prior to or
after the restraint.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 3’s interview was consistent with Staff 2’s
interview. Staff 3 added he had good rapport with Youth A and
spoke to him often. Staff 3 noted Youth A never complained about
any pain or medical issues during any of their conversations. After
Youth A received his brace for the diagnosed wrist fracture, Staff 3
asked Youth A what happened, and Youth A stated he was not
sure how he got injured. Staff 3 reported the first initial response
for circumstances involving youth fighting is to provide safety and
security to the youth/staff and then staff are to defend themselves
until other staff can arrive.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 4 reported when she entered the room and
Supervisor was on top of Youth A but could not remember
Supervisor’s position. Staff 4 reported she helped secure one of
Youth A’s legs while Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 5 secured Youth A’s
other leg and arms. Staff 4 did not see anything during the
restraint or incident that could have caused injury to Youth A’s
wrist. Staff 4 stated Youth A never said “ow” during the restraint or
complained to her about any injuries he had prior, during or after
the restraint. Staff 4 reported the only consensus she received
from debriefing with other staff was Supervisor should have waited
for additional assistance from other staff prior to restraining Youth
A, especially because Supervisor was so much bigger than Youth
A.
4

Staff 5 was interviewed face to face on-site at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Staff 5 reported she was conducting the Group
Assistance Meeting for Youth A prior to the incident occurring.
Staff 5 stated Youth A became upset after Youth B called him out
for his behavior of punching things and folding his hands in an
angry way. Staff 5 reported when Youth A began to approach
Youth B in an aggressive manor, she stepped in between them
and put her arms up to block Youth A from becoming physical with
Youth B. Staff 5 reported Youth A pushed her into the door in the
room and she fell. While she was getting up, she saw Supervisor
come into the room and secure Youth A from behind. Staff 5
reported she secured the other youth in their rooms and then
came to help restrain one of Youth A’s legs. Staff 5 reported she
did not see any actions during the incident that would have
resulted in injury to Youth A’s wrist. Staff 5 stated Youth A
previously complained to her about pain in his wrist, but stated he
got in a fight with someone before being admitted to the facility so
he guessed that might be the reason. Staff 5 stated Youth A
normally complained about his wrist hurting after playing
basketball or other activities in the gym. After Youth A was
diagnosed with a fractured wrist, he was restricted from activities
because of the wrist brace he was wearing. When Staff 5 asked
Youth A about his wrist, Youth A told Staff 5 his wrist was broken
and told her he wasn’t sure if it was broken due to the restraint or
from the fight he participated in prior to entering the facility. Staff 5
reported a debrief was held with staff and Supervisor after the
restraint and they all spoke about concerns regarding Youth A
complaining he couldn’t breathe as well as the need to wait until
more staff arrive prior to putting a youth in a restraint.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/19/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Supervisor reported when he entered the room,
Youth A was running around the table to attack Youth B, so
Supervisor bearhugged Youth A from behind. Supervisor noted a
bearhug is not ideal because the goal is to try to prevent injuries.
He noted it is not an approved CPI restraint method and is not
taught in CPI. Supervisor stated after he bearhugged him, he and
Youth A accidently fell to the ground. Supervisor reported once
they were on the ground, he attempted to get back up, but he was
unable to because Youth A wrapped his arms around Supervisor’s
left leg. Supervisor leaned on his right side trying to hold Youth A
down. Supervisor reported Youth A was trying to bite him, so he
was pushing Youth A’s head away so he could not bite. When
5

Youth A stated he couldn’t breathe, Supervisor adjusted his
position and Youth A had no further complaints. Supervisor
reported he was finally able to get up once four other staff had
individually secured Youth A’s arms and legs. Supervisor reported
he checked on Youth A later in the shift. Youth A did not have any
visible injuries and did not complain of any injuries or concerns at
that time. While Youth A was in the facility, Youth A complained of
different ailments, but never mentioned any urgent concerns or
complaints about his wrist.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/19/23 in
conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement.
Nurse completed the initial physical intake with Youth A on 1/3/23
and he had a benign ganglion cyst on his upper wrist/lower hand.
He reported it was bothersome to him because it was annoying
and unsightly, but he did not complain of any pain. He had full
range of motion and was not prescribed any medication or
treatment on 1/3/23. On 1/11/23, Nurse received a request to see
Youth A because he reported his wrist hurt bad and he couldn’t
move it without it hurting. Nurse saw him on 1/11/23 and he
complained the cyst on his wrist was the cause of the pain. Youth
A told Nurse he was restrained on 1/10/23 and said his wrist hurt
more after last night, but never stated the pain was a result of the
restraint. Nurse reiterated Youth A specifically stated his wrist
“hurt more” after last night, not that it began hurting after last night.
Due to his pain, he was seen by Physician Assistant on 1/12/23,
and the Physician Assistant ordered X-Rays. Nurse reported X-
Rays were completed on 1/13/23 and they received the results the
same day. The X-Rays showed Youth A had a small fracture in
the distant ulna with associated soft tissue swelling, but no
displacement. As a result of the X-Rays, the doctor ordered a wrist
splint for 2 weeks and wanted to follow up in one week, but Youth
A left the facility prior to the one week follow up appointment
occurring. The radiologist did not note the length of time since the
fracture occurred.
Physician Assistant (PA) was interviewed via phone on
1/30/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. PA saw Youth A
on 1/12/23 and diagnosed him with a ganglion cyst on his left
wrist. PA noted Youth A had good sensation of his fingers, good
grip strength, no significant swelling, and a full range of motion.
PA prescribed Ibuprofen for 5 days and ordered an X-Ray to
assess the cyst further as she thought it might be a bone cyst.
Youth A asked for a splint because his wrist hurt, but PA assessed
a splint was not medically necessary.
6

VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage regarding the restraint from 1/10/23 involving Youth
A was reviewed multiple times on 1/19/23. The video footage was
consistent with Supervisor and all Staff interviews showing
Supervisor bear hug Youth A, and Supervisor and Youth A fall to
the ground. The camera angle prevented the ability to see how
Supervisor was holding Youth A. Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4 and Staff
5 then all secure one of Youth A’s limbs and Supervisor got up
and moved away.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:
• MDHHS Worker’s interview with Doctor from 1/30/23.
Doctor reported he reviewed Youth A’s radiology report, but
never saw or spoke with Youth A. Doctor reported the age
of a fracture cannot be precisely determined from an X-
Ray, but there may be indicators of visible healing if the
fracture is more than 2-3 weeks old. Doctor reported the
Radiologist is the only one who could provide further
information if those healing indicators were present.
• Incident Reports dated 1/10/23 completed by Supervisor,
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Youth A, Youth B
and Youth C. Staff and Supervisor incident reports were
consistent with their interviews. In Youth A’s incident report,
he noted he was punching things on the way back from the
gym.
• Facility Management Policy: Fights, Disturbances and Use
of Force and/or Restraints (Rev. 12/21/22) states Detention
staff may use physical force to prevent imminent injury to a
youth or to another person.
• Facility Training and Staff Development Policy (Rev.
12/22/22) states Youth Specialists, Professional
Specialists, Shift Supervisors & Administrators are required
to complete a “Use of Force” training on a yearly basis.
• Supervisor completed CPI Refresher Training on 5/12/22.
Supervisor does not have any disciplinary records in his
employee file.
• Youth A’s health history summary from the facility notes no
injuries or pain associated with his wrist.
• Youth A’s medical record confirms his appointment
schedule as stated by Nurse. Youth A’s medical request
7

form he filled out on 1/11/23 states his wrist “started hurting
more after last night”. On 1/12/23, Youth A complained the
cyst on his left wrist was causing him more pain and denied
any other recent trauma to his wrist.
Analysis There is no evidence to support the restraint conducted caused
Youth A’s fractured wrist. Youth A complained about pain from his
wrist prior to the restraint occurring. In addition, there was no
evidence from the video or interviews completed which
demonstrated anyone’s actions during the incident would have
caused his wrist to be injured.
However, based upon staff interviews as well as video reviewed,
Supervisor completed an improper restraint on Youth A, which is
against the facility’s written policies.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
